awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to Harvard University, located in Cambridge, MA, will support the training of eight students for ten weeks during the summers of 2019-21. The main goal of the Evolution, Ecology, Environment (E3) REU program is to leverage the extraordinary resources of the Harvard Department of Organismic and Evolutionary Biology (OEB) and the interdepartmental Harvard University Center for the Environment (HUCE) to increase the number of students who pursue research careers in the fields of evolution and ecology, with a focus on students of color and first generation students. In addition to an intensive, mentored laboratory experience, E3 REU students will participate in several types of ancillary activities: 1) professional development seminars, including on ethics/responsible conduct of research, 2) the Leadership Alliance National Symposium (LANS) research and mentoring conference, and 3) diverse cohort-building activities. Applicants are invited to apply through the Leadership Alliance Program and indicate their interest in the Harvard E3 REU. Our goal is to reach students at undergraduate institutions who demonstrate an interest in evolution and ecology but may have limited access to this type of research on their home campuses. 

It is anticipated that a total of 24 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained over the lifetime of the program. By participating in the REU Site program, undergraduate students will have cutting edge research experiences within the context of a strong mentorship community made up of faculty, graduate students, and peers. This experience will demystify the graduate school application process, the student experience, and longterm career opportunities, with a particular goal of building confidence and psychological resiliency.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students are required to be tracked after the program and must respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information is available by visiting https://gsas.harvard.edu/diversity/outreach-programs/summer-research-opportunities-harvard, or by contacting PI (Elena Kramer, ekramer@oeb.harvard.edu), or the Co-PI (Sheila Thomas, sthomas@fas.harvard.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Evolution, Ecology, Environment REU program supported summer research experiences for undergraduate interns from 2019-2023, funding a total of 30 interns. This is six more than originally planned due to the fact that we continued to run the program remotely in 2020 and 2021 during the height of the COVID pandemic. The unused travel and housing costs for these two summers were used to support the six additional students. These thirty interns were drawn from a wide variety of undergraduate institutions, including many that were primarily undergraduate focused, such as community colleges and liberal arts colleges (Fig. 1). Their demographics were equally diverse, with 73% identifying as female, 50% as URM, and 60% as first generation and/or low income. Over the course of the five years, our applications increased from 35 in 2019 to 399 in 2023 (the first year using ETAP).

The undergraduate participants experienced both research training and professional development opportunities during the program. In terms of research, they had an opportunity to enhance their exposure to diverse methods, develop their experimental design and critical thinking skills, and increase their knowledge regarding scientific research. Through weekly workshops and discussions, they were also able to enhance their presentation skills, build their confidence in participating in scientific dialogue, broaden their knowledge of different areas of scientific research, and gain a better understanding of graduate student life and career opportunities for individuals with graduate degrees in the sciences. They further had the chance to expand their professional network both with respect to meeting peers, near-peers, and faculty and administrators within Harvard.

All of our interns had two opportunities to present their work outside of their research groups. They presented posters at a Harvard-wide poster session at the end of the summer and presented either posters or short talks at the annual Leadership Alliance conference. This conference provided them with the opportunity to network with faculty, graduate students and administrators from 35+ institutions that are members of the Leadership Alliance Consortium, and hundreds of peers participating in summer programs at these institutions. 

In addition, five of the interns have participated as co-authors in peer-reviewed publications. Of our 30 interns, five are still undergraduates, but of the 25 who have completed their Bachelor’s degrees, 11 are currently enrolled as PhD students; five are employed as research technicians; three are in post-baccalaureate programs; three are employed in roles related to conservation biology or science policy; two are employed in research industry; and one has moved back to Turkey with his family (Fig. 2). We plan to continue to track intern progress in their professional careers and provide them with support as they navigate academia and research.

Overall, the E3 REU was a successful and stimulating experience for everyone involved – undergraduate interns, research mentors, peer mentors and faculty participants. We believe this REU will continue to be a key conduit to support research training for undergraduates without access to opportunities in evolution and ecology, allowing us to promote the diversification of this foundational fields of life sciences.
